channel.title: Technology - Digg
channel.description: Technology on Digg: the best articles, videos, tweets, and original content that the web is talking about right now

item.title: At The Limits Of Thought
item.description: Science today stands at a crossroads: will its progress be driven by human minds or by the machines that we've created?

item.title: New York Needed Ventilators. So They Developed One In A Month
item.description: The pandemic inspired an innovative project to design and make a low-cost ventilator in weeks, not years.

item.title: The Convoluted Reason Why You Can't Name A File 'CON' On A Windows Computer
item.description: It may be a surprising revelation, but it turns out you can't name a folder, an image or a text file "Con" on a Windows machine.

item.title: Meet The Upscalers
item.description: Stuck indoors? Try restoring an old TV show or movie.

item.title: Magic Keyboard For The iPad Pro Review: The Best Way To Turn An iPad Into A Laptop
item.description: It's what we've all been asking for — for better or worse.

item.title: Zen And The Art Of Searching For Lost Computer Files
item.description: Spend your quarantine digging through your digital attic.
item.kicker: NOW THAT YOU HAVE THE TIME

item.title: The Decline Of Usability
item.description: In which we delve into the world of user interface design — and how it's all gone downhill.

item.title: Resellers Using Checkout Bots Are Driving The Nintendo Switch Shortage
item.description: Motherboard traced some of the recent automated Switch buying to a particular, new bot that anyone can use.

item.title: Leaked Schematics Reveal The Big Design Change Coming To The iPhone 12
item.description: According to leaked CAD schematics, the new iPhone will feature squared off edges, similar to the iPad Pro — or the old iPhone SE.

item.title: How To Make A Ventilator
item.description: To combat the coronavirus pandemic, DIY makers and companies are scrambling to create open-source ventilators. Here's what they're up against.

item.title: An Army Of Virus Tracers Takes Shape In Massachusetts
item.description: Asian countries have invested heavily in digital contact-tracing, which uses technology to warn people when they have been exposed to the coronavirus. Massachusetts is using an old-fashioned means: people.

item.title: A Computer Whiz Jerry-Rigged A 1930 Model 15 Teletype As A Linux Terminal And It's Quite Impressive
item.description: An extremely patient techie set up a 1930s teletype to be used as a Linux TTY interface.
item.kicker: SOMEONE SEND THIS TO TOM HANKS

item.title: The New iPhone SE Is A Shockingly Good Value
item.description: The most important thing to know about the SE's value proposition is simply that it has the A13 Bionic processor, which is bar-none the fastest processor you can get on any smartphone at any price, full stop.
item.kicker: GOOD THINGS COME IN SMALL PACKAGES

item.title: Even 'Small' Phones Are Big Now
item.description: Apple's new iPhone SE 2 is dramatically larger than the prior SE and signifies the end of the line for small smartphones.

item.title: Here's What You're Getting With The iPhone SE 2
item.description: How does the new iPhone SE stack up compared to the others?

item.title: Ventilators Aren't Going To Cure COVID-19. Here's What They Can Do
item.description: Since the beginning of the coronavirus outbreak, ventilators have been a key focus of the media, politicians and the president. But most of these references miss some key points.

item.title: Pokémon Go Adds Remote Raids So You Don't Have To Go Outside
item.description: Niantic is adding a new item called a Remote Raid Pass to Pokémon Go, letting you play raids that appear on the app's map or "Nearby" page without having to go to the physical location.

item.title: The Rise Of Zoom Breakups
item.description: The search for love continues — and so does the ending of once-promising relationships. Now, though, all this is happening via videoconference.

item.title: Here's Apple's New $399 iPhone SE
item.description: It has a 4.7-inch screen and a home button with Touch ID. It's available for preorder starting on April 17th, and it'll ship on April 24th.
item.kicker: THE BEZELS ARE BACK IN TOWN

item.title: Somebody Hacked Their iPad Pro To Run Mac OS X
item.description: A tech whiz found a way to run Mac OS X Leopard 10.5 on an emulator on their 2020 iPad Pro 11″ without Jailbreaking it.

item.title: The Devastating Decline Of A Brilliant Young Coder
item.description: Lee Holloway programmed internet security firm Cloudflare into being. But then he became apathetic, distant, and unpredictable — for a long time, no one could make sense of it.

item.title: A Very Close Look Inside The Mandalorian's Ship
item.description: Know what I love? Cross-sections, aka cut-aways. Know what else I love (though that love has been worn to a paper-thin nub in recent years)? Star Wars. Let's combine 'em.

item.title: This Abandoned Computer Store Is A Time Capsule Of Early 2000s Tech
item.description: In a strip mall in a small Oklahoma city, a treasure of software and hardware sits gathering dust.

item.title: Zoom Burnout Is Real
item.description: And here's what to do about it.

item.title: Folding@Home Had Settled Into A Low-Profile Niche. Then Came Coronavirus
item.description: The pandemic has turned Folding@Home into an exaFLOP supercomputer, hitting speeds more than seven times faster than the world's fastest supercomputer.

item.title: An MIT Lab Is Building Devices To Hack Your Dreams
item.description: From improving your mood to focusing your creativity, scientists at MIT's Dream Lab want to prove the power of dreams.
item.kicker: DREAM A LITTLE DREAM OF MIT

item.title: Unemployment Checks Are Being Held Up By A Coding Language Almost Nobody Knows
item.description: States have been starved of modernization funding for years
item.kicker: TIME TO CALL THE COBOL GUY

item.title: This Is A Rare Prototype Of The First Apple Watch
item.description: A collector has gotten his hands on rare prototypes of the first generation of Apple Watches, and hopes to sell them for thousands of dollars.

item.title: The Most Popular Tech Gadget From The Year You Were Born
item.description: From the remote control to the Xbox, take a look at the inventions that changed our lives through history.

item.title: A New Machine Can Translate Brain Activity Directly Into Written Sentences
item.description: Translating up to 50 sentences at once, it's about as accurate as human transcription.

item.title: Coffee Expert Gives A Brutally Frank Review Of Aldi's New $375 Espresso Machine
item.description: James Hoffmann, a coffee expert who's been in the business since 2003, reviewed the budget grocery store's premiere espresso maker. He wasn't that impressed.
item.kicker: 'WE'RE JUST NOT GOING TO BE FRIENDS'

item.title: The World's Smartphones Are Filled With Gold. That's A Problem
item.description: Small amounts of gold used in electronics quickly add up to environmental and humanitarian disasters.

item.title: It's Time To Delete Your Delivery Apps
item.description: For weeks, as restaurants begged delivery platforms to reduce their commissions, the apps refused, further profiting from the coronavirus crisis.

item.title: Edward Snowden Explains Why He's Worried About Civil Liberties In The Response To The Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: Edward Snowden tells Vice co-founder Shane Smith he fears the spread of authoritarianism in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak.

item.title: This Man Owns The World's Most Advanced Private Air Force After Buying 46 F/A-18 Hornets
item.description: We talked to the owner of Air USA about probably the most incredible private aircraft purchase of all time and the future of his adversary business.

item.title: A Company Promised Cheap Ventilators To The Government, Never Delivered And Is Now Charging Quadruple The Price For New Ones
item.description: Royal Philips N.V. agreed in September to sell 10,000 ventilators to the US for $3,280 each. It did not deliver. But the Dutch company just announced a new deal with the government. This time, it's charging roughly $15,000 each.

item.title: Which Cars Will Be The Last To Offer A Manual Transmission?
item.description: Manual transmissions still enjoy huge market share overseas, but the numbers are in decline, and the vehicle classes keeping it alive are not what you think.

item.title: This Is What The Future Of Human Evolution Looks Like
item.description: "Science and human advancement has always been propelled forward by the people who do things differently and those who are not afraid to break the rules."

item.title: McLaren Thinks Synthetic Fuel Could Save The Engine As We Know It
item.description: The technology could be a battery-electric alternative and still reduce emissions when taking battery production into account.

item.title: Has Apple Finally Bitten Off Way More Than It Can Chew?
item.description: Apple used to be about changing the world one magic box at a time. Now it's fighting to conquer TV drama, healthcare, money, news and much else besides.
item.kicker: RISKY, BUT THEY'VE BEEN THERE BEFORE

item.title: Filmmaker Reacts To The Incredibly Realistic Scenes In Movies That Are Actually Special Effects
item.description: Peter McKinnon is continually shocked by the extremely real looking fake scenes in modern Hollywood features.
item.kicker: EVEN BETTER THAN THE REAL THING

item.title: The Boeing 737 Max's Big Problem? Its Computers Have The Processing Power Of A Super Nintendo
item.description: While Boeing has received plenty of scrutiny for its bad code, it's the Max's computing power — or lack thereof — that has kept it on the ground since then.

item.title: Our Government Runs On A 60-Year-Old Coding Language, And Now It's Falling Apart
item.description: Over the weekend, New Jersey governor Phil Murphy made an unusual public plea during his daily coronavirus briefing: The state was seeking volunteer programmers who know COBOL.

item.title: We're On The Brink Of Cyberpunk
item.description: The real future may be more Amazon and less androids, but the dystopian power dynamics are hard to miss.

item.title: A Toilet With Facial Recognition For Your Butthole
item.description: Data gathering for toilets using biometrics of your anus. Got it? Okay, cool.

item.title: 'Every Day Is A New Surprise': Inside The Effort To Produce The World's Most Popular Coronavirus Tracker
item.description: How a small university team built a COVID-19 data site that draws 1 billion clicks a day.

item.title: Silicon Valley's Newest Obsession: An Anonymously Created 'Hot Guys Of Tech' List
item.description: The 15-person ranking is entertaining the nation's technorati who are eagerly browsing the list, debating its selections and staring at it in bemused horror.

item.title: How The Far-Right Helped Create The World's Most Powerful Facial Recognition Technology
item.description: Even if you've never heard of Clearview, you likely have an online presence which means you're probably in its database.

item.title: A Top Hollywood Camera Operator Demonstrates The Eye-Popping Ability Of 'The World's Most Advanced Camera Stabilizer'
item.description: "It's almost like you have a third arm coming out the side of your hip."

item.title: This Tiny Startup Thinks It Can Do Email Better Than Google
item.description: After years of building email apps, Edison decided the only way to fix email was to do it from the ground up. With OnMail, it's taking on Gmail head on.
